{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3394012,"name":"Alex Tsekhansky","username":"atsekhan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/0ea827/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-31T20:33:51.944Z","cooked":"

Our team uses PathPlanner for trajectories and Java as our main programming language. We use Pigeon IMU to track chassis angle relative to the field.
We can do pretty sophisticated auto routines. However, we did not yet master precision in-place turns for our swerve drive (meaning - with the acceptable error being less than 1 degree at all times, if you’re not bumped). The process uses software PID, and due to the robot’s friction curve, the turn-in-place-from-stopped position proved to be a challenge.

An angle is tracked by an IMU with relatively low YAW drift (say, much less than 0.01 in 5 second period).

We would like to accomplish the turn in the fastest way possible. Hence, we really would like to use PID without the Ki. That means we really would like a way to calibrate a PD-based turn.

The issue seems to be related to relatively high force required to overcome friction from STOP. So, high P values, especially on the 20ms cycle seem to make the robot overshoot, and the D values do not compensate enough, so the PID is either considered done, or stops and never overcomes friction again.
So, one possible fix is to create a “deadband” force - a minimum force for the robot to start turning, and if the PID wants the robot to move in certain direction, apply that minimum. The issue with that - that force might change at times due to the external factors. I suppose a fairly large I can be added in this case to guarantee it moving.
I am also considering running two PID routines in sequence - one that is very fast and does a rough turn (e.g. to 5-10 degrees precision), and once done, run another one, with much smaller P value, hence working much slower, to turn to the desired angle.

I was wondering how does your team solve that challenge?

I saw several teams executing perfect angle headings in auto, and I am wondering if they have a way to do so I am not aware of.

Thanks.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":44,"updated_at":"2024-05-31T20:33:51.944Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":150,"reads":538,"readers_count":537,"score":877.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":467079,"topic_slug":"turn-chassis-to-angle-on-swerve-with-high-precision-and-speed","display_username":"Alex Tsekhansky","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50762,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/turn-chassis-to-angle-on-swerve-with-high-precision-and-speed/467079/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3394034,"name":"Kaleb Dodd","username":"Kaleb_Dodd","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kaleb_dodd/{size}/7859_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-31T22:19:45.657Z","cooked":"

It is difficult to make a turn PID that can handle 90 degree and 3 degree turns with the same gains.

One way is to limit the maximum output of the turning pid so that when making large turns there isn’t such a massive momentum difference compared to making small turns.

I would consider some slight i if you plan on using this pid to aim to a goal, but make sure to have the range at which i is added to be small such as 5 degrees so it doesn’t build up on large turns. I believe the WPILIB pid doesn’t have that option but instead has a maximum i value which can also work but not as effectively as an I range from my experience.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":44,"updated_at":"2024-05-31T22:19:45.657Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":471,"readers_count":470,"score":109.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":467079,"topic_slug":"turn-chassis-to-angle-on-swerve-with-high-precision-and-speed","display_username":"Kaleb Dodd","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":23840,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/turn-chassis-to-angle-on-swerve-with-high-precision-and-speed/467079/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3394041,"name":"Eugene Fang","username":"Eugene_Fang","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/eugene_fang/{size}/65109_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-31T22:53:13.318Z","cooked":"
Kaleb_Dodd:

It is difficult to make a turn PID that can handle 90 degree and 3 degree turns with the same gains.

This shouldn’t be an issue if you’re also utilizing a feedforward term in your control loop. I believe a ProfiledPIDController in wpilib handles this for you.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":44,"updated_at":"2024-05-31T22:59:41.946Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":430,"readers_count":429,"score":146.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":467079,"topic_slug":"turn-chassis-to-angle-on-swerve-with-high-precision-and-speed","display_username":"Eugene Fang","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":"The-Blue-Alliance","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/0/2/02b18ea7720fea44e77469bb5261acf1c7045a6e.png","flair_bg_color":"","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":67,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7439,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"604 Alum & Mentor | The Blue Alliance"},"post_url":"/t/turn-chassis-to-angle-on-swerve-with-high-precision-and-speed/467079/3","custom_user_title":"604 Alum & Mentor | The Blue Alliance","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3394085,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-01T01:42:23.533Z","cooked":"

Are you running velocity control on your wheel speeds? That should already be taking care of static friction at low speeds.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":44,"updated_at":"2024-06-01T01:42:23.533Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":364,"readers_count":363,"score":92.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":467079,"topic_slug":"turn-chassis-to-angle-on-swerve-with-high-precision-and-speed","display_username":"Tom Line","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7841,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 1498"},"post_url":"/t/turn-chassis-to-angle-on-swerve-with-high-precision-and-speed/467079/4","custom_user_title":"Team 1498","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3394089,"name":"Alex Tsekhansky","username":"atsekhan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/0ea827/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-06-01T02:07:24.882Z","cooked":"

I do not run velocity control on the wheel speed. The swerve gets the arraty of ModuleStates that translates eventually to the powers applied to a wheel in the module. The translation is based on the estimated max velocity and max acceleration.
One way or the other - at the very low level it’s still voltage applied to the drive motors. So, the question is - how would one use PID to do it?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":44,"updated_at":"2024-06-01T02:07:24.882Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":351,"readers_count":350,"score":75.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":467079,"topic_slug":"turn-chassis-to-angle-on-swerve-with-high-precision-and-speed","display_username":"Alex Tsekhansky","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":7841,"username":"Tom_Line","name":"Tom Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50762,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/turn-chassis-to-angle-on-swerve-with-high-precision-and-speed/467079/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3394090,"name":"Alex Tsekhansky","username":"atsekhan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/0ea827/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-06-01T02:10:42.417Z","cooked":"

So, I did research and detailed characterization of the robot. The FeedForward, while looks fine on the surface, is not quite as applicable, because it takes more power to make robot moving from “stationary” position than stop from “moving” position.

In our robot, for instance, it takes on average 0.055 percent power (per wheel - I printed that) to make the robot moving, yet, once moving, it will stop at the power below 0.053. That makes sense because the friction in a stationary unit is less than a moving one.
In addition, feed-forward assumes constant force direction. However, if you overshoot, you need to return back, and the feedforward there would need to be reversed.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":44,"updated_at":"2024-06-01T02:10:42.417Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":330,"readers_count":329,"score":71.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":467079,"topic_slug":"turn-chassis-to-angle-on-swerve-with-high-precision-and-speed","display_username":"Alex Tsekhansky","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":7439,"username":"Eugene_Fang","name":"Eugene Fang","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/eugene_fang/{size}/65109_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50762,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/turn-chassis-to-angle-on-swerve-with-high-precision-and-speed/467079/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3394095,"name":"Alex Tsekhansky","username":"atsekhan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/0ea827/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-06-01T02:19:05.420Z","cooked":"

That is my current direction. However, I think precision estimates might help me to deal with possibly just one formula. For instance, we measured today that the maximum rotation speed of our robot is 801-811 degrees per second - which means 2.253 rotations per second. With 20ms cycle that means in 20ms you get to 16.22 degrees per cycle. Since you also need 1 cycle to react, it means the maximum value of P can be 1/(2*16.22) (probably lower actually) if the error is measured in degrees, in order for the robot to slow down from full speed properly.
The precise max acceleration measurement will actually allow me to determine the minimum number of cycles I need to have in order to slow down.
As I said, I am trying to avoid I in PID, and may be even avoid D.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":44,"updated_at":"2024-06-01T02:28:44.287Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":304,"readers_count":303,"score":70.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":467079,"topic_slug":"turn-chassis-to-angle-on-swerve-with-high-precision-and-speed","display_username":"Alex Tsekhansky","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":23840,"username":"Kaleb_Dodd","name":"Kaleb Dodd","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kaleb_dodd/{size}/7859_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50762,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/turn-chassis-to-angle-on-swerve-with-high-precision-and-speed/467079/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3394108,"name":"Justin Hollister","username":"Bullzombie","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/b5ac83/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-06-01T03:12:18.831Z","cooked":"

I think he was suggesting that you use feedforward along side a normal feedback loop.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":44,"updated_at":"2024-06-01T03:12:18.831Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":283,"readers_count":282,"score":76.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":467079,"topic_slug":"turn-chassis-to-angle-on-swerve-with-high-precision-and-speed","display_username":"Justin Hollister","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":50762,"username":"atsekhan","name":"Alex Tsekhansky","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/0ea827/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64179,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Melon"},"post_url":"/t/turn-chassis-to-angle-on-swerve-with-high-precision-and-speed/467079/8","custom_user_title":"Melon","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3394125,"name":"paulonis","username":"paulonis","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/5fc32e/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-06-01T04:44:52.101Z","cooked":"
atsekhan:

I do not run velocity control on the wheel speed.

atsekhan:

The issue seems to be related to relatively high force required to overcome friction from STOP.

The first thing you should try is to add closed-loop velocity control to your swerve wheels. This velocity control should include feedforward and feedback controllers. The feedforward controller should include a static gain (often referred to as kS). The purpose of this is to overcome static friction in the drive modules directly and instantly rather than trying to get the drive feedback controller to manage that along with other velocity errors.

The better the drive velocity control, the easier it is for a chassis rotation controller to perform its role well.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":44,"updated_at":"2024-06-01T04:44:52.101Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":2,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":279,"readers_count":278,"score":95.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":467079,"topic_slug":"turn-chassis-to-angle-on-swerve-with-high-precision-and-speed","display_username":"paulonis","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22261,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/turn-chassis-to-angle-on-swerve-with-high-precision-and-speed/467079/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3394148,"name":"kylelanman","username":"kylelanman","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kylelanman/{size}/3427_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-01T11:51:34.835Z","cooked":"

Use the gyro to determine the error. From the error calculate the arc distance each wheel needs to travel. Use MotionMagic / MotionProfile to drive the length. Update the setpoint from the gyro error each loop.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":44,"updated_at":"2024-06-01T11:51:34.835Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":248,"readers_count":247,"score":84.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":467079,"topic_slug":"turn-chassis-to-angle-on-swerve-with-high-precision-and-speed","display_username":"kylelanman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9953,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/turn-chassis-to-angle-on-swerve-with-high-precision-and-speed/467079/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3394175,"name":"Alex Tsekhansky","username":"atsekhan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/0ea827/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-06-01T14:49:54.411Z","cooked":"

And that’s one technique I was considering. I think one of the main issue is that the turn has very little distance to travel, and software PID simply does not check things often enough.
Our drivetrain is CTR-based (Falcons + pigeon), so I can do proper hardware PID to do so. Nevertheless, since Pigeon is on CAN, the angle correction will still be outside 1ms loop.

What does your team do?

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":44,"updated_at":"2024-06-01T14:49:54.411Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":225,"readers_count":224,"score":45.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":467079,"topic_slug":"turn-chassis-to-angle-on-swerve-with-high-precision-and-speed","display_username":"Alex Tsekhansky","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":9953,"username":"kylelanman","name":"kylelanman","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kylelanman/{size}/3427_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50762,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/turn-chassis-to-angle-on-swerve-with-high-precision-and-speed/467079/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3394178,"name":"Alex Tsekhansky","username":"atsekhan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/0ea827/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-06-01T14:57:44.502Z","cooked":"

I think I understand what you mean.

Just like everyone else, our module gets edu.wpi.first.math.kinematics.SwerveModuleState object.

However, instead of running velocity PID, I am doing this for drive -

driveMotorApplyPower(desiredState.speedMetersPerSecond / SwerveChassis.MAX_VELOCITY);

In other words, I convert desired velocity state to desired power state I guess the suggestion is to change this to velocity PID instead.

Our prior experiments with Velocity PID on CTR motors did not go too well, especially in situations with very low load.

Any suggestions on how to do proper characterization related to velocity PID to determine the constants properly?

Eugene_Fang:

I believe a ProfiledPIDController in wpilib handles this for you.

Accounting for FF isn’t what ProfiledPIDController does and not what it aims to do. WPILib has classes to calculate FF for different cases and also documents how to combine this with PID.

truher","username":"truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-01T15:33:29.995Z","cooked":"

@atsekhan i think you can study the topic of minimum-time rotational control by simplifying the situation. try a simple experiment: rotate the robot 90 degrees, from rest to rest. what’s the fastest motor control profile? minimum-time profiles are always “bang bang” i.e. all you need to figure out is when to switch the motor polarity and when to stop.

I bet you could build a very simple test command that rotates the wheels to the correct orientation (45 degrees) and then applies a bang bang drive profile, and you could end up pretty close to a 90 degree rotation, pretty consistently, without any feedback at all.

that experiment might inform the best way to produce the same kind of minimum-time drive profiles from a more integrated controller.

You’re right, I should’ve double checked what it does before posting about it, since we don’t actually use it.

If using a ProfiledPIDController, you’d want to use the controller setpoint velocity as a feed forward for the rotational velocity of the chassis.

The point is that you don’t want the closed loop PID to be responsible for dealing with large ranges of error (e.g. a couple of degrees up to 180 degrees). By having feedforward part do most of the work, the closed loop part is only responsible for closing off small errors.

Yes, that’s what my next step would be.

We turn the wheel to angle using hardware PID with built-in sensors, so we’re on 1ms loop, and the turn is VERY fast.

Once the run is done, I can indeed apply the hardware distance PID based on the estimated arc size, and correct the PID on 20ms loop based on the IMU readings either via RIO or secondary PID - I will need to think about that one.

So, not that straightforward, but certainly doable.

I am just wondering how the other teams do it? I do not think we’re the only ones faced with the problem.

Also I looked at the code done by other folks, such as YAGSL, and they indeed use the Velocity PID for the drive wheels. The question I have - how does one come up with the proper PID constant values for the drive wheels velocity PID?

I guess that question is somewhat unrelated to my original one, but would still be useful for the swerve summer optimization project

atsekhan:

I can indeed apply the hardware distance PID

That’s not what i’m suggesting. I’m saying you can just use a timer. “all drive motors at 100% forward for 0.45 sec, then all motors 100% reverse for 0.1 sec, then all motors stop.”

What other teams do is that they don’t try to rotate as fast as possible. They have other competing requirements, like preventing wheel-spin, moderating control effort, combining rotation and translation, simplifying control logic, etc.

… But that doesn’t mean you shouldn’t explore this topic! Simple, focused experiments to explore the limits of control are a great idea! You’ll learn a lot about what optimal control looks like!

","post_number":18,"post_type":1,"posts_count":44,"updated_at":"2024-06-01T17:08:47.954Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":16,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":171,"readers_count":170,"score":34.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":467079,"topic_slug":"turn-chassis-to-angle-on-swerve-with-high-precision-and-speed","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/turn-chassis-to-angle-on-swerve-with-high-precision-and-speed/467079/18","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3394203,"name":"joel truher","username":"truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-01T17:21:29.722Z","cooked":"

re: setting the “P” value for the outboard controller, you can see what the CTRE outboard controller is doing using getClosedLoopError(). You won’t be able to see it at full resolution of 1 khz, but low-rate samples will still be useful.

","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":44,"updated_at":"2024-06-01T17:21:29.722Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":17,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":163,"readers_count":162,"score":32.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":467079,"topic_slug":"turn-chassis-to-angle-on-swerve-with-high-precision-and-speed","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":50762,"username":"atsekhan","name":"Alex Tsekhansky","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/0ea827/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/turn-chassis-to-angle-on-swerve-with-high-precision-and-speed/467079/19","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3394204,"name":"Allen Nuttle","username":"nuttle","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuttle/{size}/124105_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-01T17:23:48.204Z","cooked":"

In general, PID isn’t a good starting point these days. You should consider trapezoidal/exponential PID instead – this is what the motion profiling is typically doing. But, it’s probably easier to start out by running things on your RIO, and some motors are basically going to require that you do this. To make it work with the onboard motor controller logic, your motor controller needs to be able to accept feedback input from your IMU.
